audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a spoken statement from a male speaker expressing concern about widespread disagreement and differing values. His tone is serious, questioning how to deal with such conflicts.  He wonders if continuing the conflict would cause harm, and then he restates his concern. Light music then starts playing. It is slow and relaxing, possibly for background purposes.

A male speaker introduces a problem and suggests a solution involving an individual. The speaker promotes a documentary titled "Accidental Courtesy," sounding informative. Mild background music is present throughout, creating an unobtrusive ambience.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a person who has spent 30 years traveling the country, having conversations and forming friendships with members of the Ku Klux Klan. He poses the question of why someone would choose to talk to their worst enemies instead of fighting. This fades into a different male speaker with a reflective tone, asking, "How can you hate me when you don't even know me?" and states that he has been looking for an answer to that throughout his life.

The clip begins with a male speaker announcing his intent to "begin seeking out members of the Ku Klux Klan", speaking with an inquisitive tone. This transitions into a male speaker with a thoughtful and analytical tone, reflecting upon this decision. He notes that finding out more led Darryl "on a mission to seek out and engage with high ranking members of the KKK".

A male speaker describes how he has invited people into his home, had conversations with them, and considers some of them friends, despite how unlikely it seems. Another male speaker interjects, asserting that Tom Robb would say he is not his friend, and that he, the speaker, is Tom Robb's friend. He expresses hope that Tom Robb will eventually come around.

The clip begins with a male speaker suggesting that Darryl might dismiss his actions as simply treating people with respect and kindness. He concedes that this is true, before adding that it's a rare quality even when risks are low.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker defending a particular approach, stating that it "has a lot of empirical support" from neuroscientists and psychologists who study persuasion. He uses a calm and explanatory tone, citing psychological studies that indicate people's emotions can hijack their rational minds and cause them to react defensively when their core beliefs are challenged. He continues, explaining that, presenting conflicting arguments may backfire. He further states "We also know a lot about how to talk to people in ways that are actually persuasive."

The clip begins with soft, contemplative background music that establishes a thoughtful atmosphere. A male voice begins speaking in a calm, informative tone, discussing Robert Cialdini's principles of persuasion, specifically focusing on reciprocity, which he explains is "based on the idea that people feel obliged to treat you the way you treat them". The music continues softly under his narration. He adds that kindness and humility typically elicit similar responses, while contempt can lead to a negative outcome. He ends with the rhetorical question, "Well, what do you think?".

The clip opens with a male speaker firmly asserting that he doesn't support racist agendas or supremacy, but advocates for freedom of speech and expression of views, noting that doing so is reciprocated. This transitions into a discussion by a second male speaker, with an intellectual and thoughtful tone, on the principle of "liking." He emphasizes that if someone likes you and believes you like them, it's easier to convince them to consider your way of thinking.

The audio clip starts with a calm male voice describing how listening and finding common ground is a shortcut to friendship, and uses an example of Darryl Davis who might have nothing in common with KKK members. This transitions into another male speaker with a slightly raspy voice who says that spending just "five minutes" with your "arch enemy" will reveal commonalities, and that "skin color" will matter "less and less" as the shared ground expands. The clip concludes with the initial male voice noting that these relationships have had "an interesting side effect".

The clip features a male speaker discussing white supremacists and their changes of heart, mentioning "hung up their robes and hoods" and potentially breaking cycles of "bigotry." He speaks in a conversational tone. There are no other distinguishable voices or musical elements present.

The audio begins with a young girl identifying herself as Aaron and stating her age. She speaks in a neutral tone when discussing her parents belonging to organizations, and when asked about it says she thinks it is "fine". She expresses her belief that they are "allowed to like their race" and that she will also be a member of their group. This is followed by a male speaker who announces that both daughters are now in the Klan and that their father was sentenced to ten years in federal prison. The speaker says that they plan to call the mother, named Tina. The audio clip ends abruptly.

The clip begins with a male speaker detailing a story of a man affiliated with the KKK who drove people out to see their father in prison, something that no one else had done for them before. Following this, a female speaker chimes in, reflecting on how her child came a long way despite her and the father's efforts, to seemingly sabotage their kids. There are no apparent background sounds or music in the clip.

The clip begins with a woman expressing well wishes, mentioning a celebration of Dr. Martin Luther King and stating that neither she nor her family are currently affiliated with the Ku Klux Klan. This speech transitions to a man speaking about the prevailing attitude of responding to hate with more hate, anger, outrage, and even violence, adopting a concerned tone.

The clip begins with one person, a man, speaking with a contemplative tone. He references Dan Harmon and indicates disagreement with the notion that "the time for talking was over." This is followed by a separate audio segment featuring a male voice declaring, "We have sat, we have talked, we have argued, we have pondered; the discourse is over" in a resolute tone. The clip then concludes with the first male speaker responding with "But I disagree."

The clip begins with a male speaker, in a thoughtful tone, discussing how humanity's ability to engage in peaceful dialogue and free speech has led to increased civilization, transitioning into a second, confident-sounding male speaker stating he respected the first person's right to speak despite not respecting the content. The clip concludes with a non-distinct ambient noise.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing techniques for convincing people, contrasting "diehard white supremacists" with "friends, neighbors, and co-workers." His tone is persuasive, suggesting that genuine conversations can lead to personal growth. This transitions into a section where he discusses dealing with "wrong or evil ideas" by making "a friend out of an enemy," which is delivered in a reflective tone.

The audio begins with a friendly, conversational introduction to a show called "Out of Frame," followed by a call to action for viewer feedback and subscription.  This is followed by suggesting the viewers to check out "@fee online" on social media. The clip has one male speaker.
